creditline: Gift of the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture
description: landscape with mountains and water: tree lined mountain range near top; shore and peninsula lined with small huts; tall cliffs on either side frame the water; at bottom, a tall pine tree creates depth; at LL, a small figure in white robe with walking stick looks out onto scene
inscription: URQ: 緑石求魚水清淺隔雲聴鳥; 樹扶疎出門行楽復還室斜日; 在窓重読書　時在昭和戊辰仲; 夏於東山草堂(Along the rocks I search for fish / where water\'s clear and shallow; / Beyond the clouds I hear the birds / where trees spread in profusion. / I go out my gate to enjoy myself, / then return back home; / As setting sunlight shines through the window / again I read my books.)by SA mid summer 1928 at house in Higashiyama
markings: URC, rectangular relief: 天心{Tenshin}; upper center, L of signatue, square intaglio: 福田世耕; upper center, square relief: 静處; LLC, square relief: 蓬莱山下人
signed: URQ: 古道人詩画{poet written and painted by Kodō-jin}
text: Rendered in varying shades of black and gray, this work shows Fukuda Kodōjin’s extreme use of spatial contrasts. By employing different angles for foreground, center, and background, he creates a complex composition with multiple vantage points. Along the rocks I search for fish where water’s clear and shallow; Beyond the clouds I hear the birds where trees spread in profusion. I go out my gate to enjoy myself, then return back home; As setting sunlight shines through the window again I read my books. (Trans. by Jonathan Chaves)
title: Glowing Pines and Sailboats
